Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Biotic Surveys of Central Saharan Oases
Award.AbstractNarration: This collaborative research project aims to survey comprehensively the fauna of isolated desert oases in Libya and Egypt. Surveys will focus on vertebrate and parasite diversity, with focal research on amphibians, fishes, reptiles, mollusks, and schistosome and hematozoan parasites. Using new GIS data and geo-referenced historical records, the geographical relationship between the Mediterranean and sub-Saharan faunas will be mapped. With a new collection of specimens that includes tissue samples, long-standing biogeographic hypotheses will be tested via molecular phylogenetic methods. By revisiting historical localities, important new data will be provided on changes in faunal composition driven by recent aridification. Analyses of new genetic, morphological, and ecological data will also provide a window into the evolutionary dynamics of refugial populations, including adaptation to extreme environments. Specimens, tissues, and data will be deposited in publicly accessible U.S. museum collections and databases and will serve as an important resource for future work on North African biodiversity. New distributional data on parasites, including schistosome worms, and on venomous snakes will have a direct effect on managing human health. These isolated oases are threatened by climate change, including a water table that is diminishing because of regional changes in water utilization; the investigators? surveys will draw attention to the fragility of these irreplaceable ecosystems. Through collaboration with foreign and U.S. museums, important historical specimen collections from Libya and Egypt will be updated and curated. This project includes diverse specialties and institutions, and integrates North African researchers and students in fieldwork and the resulting research. Undergraduate and graduate students will be included in both field surveys and subsequent research. This project will provide the resources for conducting taxonomic revisions, pursuing broad-scale phylogeographic studies, and applying molecular genetic tools to long-standing problems in African biogeography. This project is co-funded by the National Science Foundation's Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We studied evolutionary patterns of amphibians and reptiles throughout Africa but concentrated on areas that were particularly poorly known (Angola and Libya) as well as areas of especially high diversity (Cameroon and Namibia). Within these areas we collected, identified and described new species of reptiles; assembled, verified, and georeferenced existing museum and literature records; and combined these with our newly collected data. We used molecular phylogenetic and phylogeographic methods to determine evolutionary patterns of relationship among a diversity of reptile groups, including geckos, skinks, lacertids, and shovel-nosed snakes. We identified evolutionary patterns at several spatial scales. At the highest level we identified previously unknown patterns linking southern Australian and African leaf-toed geckos via overwater dispersal, we demonstrated that the gecko fauna of North Africa was derived from a larger Middle Eastern/Central Asia group approximately 46 million years ago, and we demonstrated that the dominant group of terrestrial skinks in Africa arrived from Asia approximately 55 million years ago and subsequently gave rise to the main skink radiation of the tropical Americas. Within Africa we have identified patterns of genealogical relationship within numerous lineages that have not been investigated previously. These have allowed us to address questions such as the evolution of limb loss and live birth in skinks, the evolution of egg-eating adaptations in snakes, and the secondary derivation of diurnal vision in geckos. Our research in Libya, Namibia and Angola has resulted in the comprehensive mapping of all locality records for these countries, providing the first realistic estimate of herpetofaunal diversity in the last of these, and demonstrating its critical significance as an area of faunal turnover from arid southwestern Africa to humid central Africa. This has revealed distributional patterns that are informative with respect to both evolutionary and ecological patterns at scales ranging from the populational to the familial, and has identified areas that are in need of further biodiversity exploration. The data have additional practical applications such as the mapping of the distribution of dangerously venomous snakes and of vertebrate malarial strains. Collectively, this project has contributed to the biotic inventory of Africa, which remains one the most poorly documented regions of the world.

This research has strengthened U.S. scientific infrastructure by providing technical training in laboratory and field techniques in systematics to nine Masters students, including five women, by contributing several thousand museum and DNA tissue samples to publically accessible collections, by generating more than 7000 DNA sequences that are being made available through public databases, and by disseminating the findings of our research in 32 peer-reviewed journal articles, 1 book, 4 book chapters and approximately 30 conference presentations.
